body: Add Exosphere and two new technologies, Elm and Ansible.
Add xguard, a simple guard clauses library to gatekeep your functions
Adding New Repository link which is a Browser Extension that will generate QR code based on the user input.
Update data.json: "Advice for writing LaTeX documents"
Update data.json: "Advice for writing LaTeX documents"
Added [torchvision](https://github.com/pytorch/vision) to the JSON file. Similar to Pytorch, torchvision too has many  open issues to be solved.
Added Deepnote coding environment to python.
RipMe is an album ripper for various websites. It is a cross-platform tool that runs on your computer and requires Java 8. RipMe has been tested and confirmed to work on Windows, Linux, and macOS.
Add KVSToK - a CLI-base KEY VALUE storage, that can be used to store system variables and recovered during shell executions or to maintain secure during lives without show the content.

Added PyNotion to the list.

Documentation: https://github.com/pythonhubpy/PyNotion
Repository: https://github.com/pythonhubpy/PyNotion

PyNotion is a wrapper client / SDK for the `Notion.so` APIs developed in Python.

Current Features:
- Querying a database
- Creating a database

Language: Python

Hi there! 

Hoping that we can be added to this list. Scribe is still relatively new, but we're slowly making headway towards v2.0 that adds autocomplete and autosuggest - the last two must have features for a wider audience. The app's data is mostly from [Wikidata](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Main_Page) and Wikipedia, and we're a [featured project](https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/New_Developers) for developers who are new to Wikimedia :) 

Hope that everything's in order for the PR, and thanks for this list!
* Add Brain Marks, an open source iOS app that allows users to save and categorize their tweets. This project is written with SwiftUI and uses the Twitter API
[sButtons](https://github.com/sButtons/sbuttons) repository is now archived and not accepting new PRs. This was the only repo under the CSS category so I am removing it.

I suggest to add [jupyterlab-lsp](https://github.com/krassowski/jupyterlab-lsp) repository (which implements coding assistance for JupyterLab) where we maintain a list of issues dedicated to beginner contributors; our issues for beginners (`good first issue` and `documentation`):
- provide a description of what should be done (and what are the possible solutions)
- link to relevant parts of codebase
- are held for new contributors for at least two weeks since creation
 
We also a pretty detailed [`CONTRIBUTING.md`](https://github.com/krassowski/jupyterlab-lsp/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and as a co-maintainer I am willing to guide any newcomers. I added the project into Typescript category, although a sizeable portion includes a Python backend. It is not clear to me what we should do if a project fits into more than one category.

[CXXCTP](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP) is a transpiler that extends C++ for new introspection, reflection and compile-time execution. New contributors are always welcome! We are looking for developers, testers and people to help with our documentation, (but, generally, any help is welcome!). The project is under an `MIT` [license](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP/blob/master/LICENSE.md). For more details on how to contribute, please check here: [Contributing](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md) Issues marked with "[help wanted](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22help+wanted%22)" and "[good first issue](https://github.com/blockspacer/CXXCTP/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22)" are good candidate tasks for new-joiners.
